sub_topic: Applying the Fourier transform to signal processing
message_1: A signal consists of a periodic square wave with a frequency of 10 Hz and a peak amplitude of 5 volts. Using the Fourier transform, calculate the frequency and amplitude of the harmonics up to the fifth order.
message_2:
A periodic square wave can be represented as a sum of its odd harmonics using the Fourier series. The general formula for the amplitude of the nth harmonic is given by:

An = (2 * Vp) / (n * π)

where An is the amplitude of the nth harmonic, Vp is the peak amplitude of the square wave (5 volts in this case), and n is the harmonic number (odd integers).

The frequency of the nth harmonic is given by:

fn = n * f0

where fn is the frequency of the nth harmonic, n is the harmonic number, and f0 is the fundamental frequency (10 Hz in this case).

We will calculate the frequency and amplitude of the harmonics up to the fifth order (n = 1, 3, 5).

1st Harmonic (n = 1):
A1 = (2 * 5) / (1 * π) ≈ 3.1831 V
f1 = 1 * 10 = 10 Hz

3rd Harmonic (n = 3):
A3 = (2 * 5) / (3 * π) ≈ 1.0610 V
f3 = 3 * 10 = 30 Hz

5th Harmonic (n = 5):
A5 = (2 * 5) / (5 * π) ≈ 0.6366 V
f5 = 5 * 10 = 50 Hz

So, the frequency and amplitude of the harmonics up to the fifth order are:

1st Harmonic: 10 Hz, 3.1831 V
3rd Harmonic: 30 Hz, 1.0610 V
5th Harmonic: 50 Hz, 0.6366 V
